Everyday Astronaut,
Yesterday I watched (a part of) the re-entry of Inspiration 4.
In the accurately planned sequence of events I was surprised by the following.
First they did the re-entry burn. And after that they closed the canopee/hatch that covers the dome.
I think they should close it first and then do the re-entry burn.
Why?
If the canopee fails to close or delays, the re-entry is initiated and no time is left for any retries or so.
If they would close it before the burn they may have more options.
Can you comment on this?
Kind regards
Carlo.

Tim, I was disappointed you were "Overcome" by emotion.  This is, after all, just another billionaire stunt.  A bit more elaborate perhaps, but still the same.  This guy hired a dragon capsule and a launcher to send him further up than anyone's been for a while, adding to the drama (and danger, like 100x or maybe even 1000x more dangerous than either earlier billionaire stunt).  Yes, they trained, but they are NOT astronauts.  They are still - civilians.  Anything goes wrong where they're at now, and buh bye most likely.  But they know that, part of their training, and they went anyway.  Hat's off to the others on the crew.  I think that Jared dude is a schmuck for putting them up there so far and putting them in so much danger.  That's his EGO operating - it was obvious from the interviews.

Great stuff as usual ... but my pedantic side can't help but question Tim's assertions about Jupiter ... all gas?  I've paused my next-day playback - maybe they'll be a correction.  I thought current conventional wisdom says Jupiter did start off with a rocky core, and then of course we have lots of metallic hydrogen etc. ... it's not just one big cloud of gas anyway!  Assuming you could somehow survive the pressure, you'd end-up standing, sort of, on something.  I guess once Tim has finished becoming expert in rocketry and related physics ... then he'll have to turn to planetary science.  :)
